title: Teenagers stranded on reef in Hamelin Bay, Western Australia after being circled by six sharks
text:
A group of teenagers came just inches away from disaster after six sharks circled around them - leaving them stranded on a reef for nearly two hours.

Jedd Falloon, 16, and his friends Toby Howe, 16, and Emilio Gianfrancesco, 17, were spearfishing in Hamelin Bay in Western Australia on Sunday when a bronze whaler lunged at them.

As the three desperately climbed onto the reef, they were horrified to see five more sharks closing in on the rocks.

The three teenagers were stranded on a reef in Hamelin Bay, Western Australia after they were attacked by a bronze whaler shark (pictured)

The group had just caught a large fish before seeing one of the sharks swimming straight towards them.

'Out of nowhere this shark just came through at 100 miles an hour and hit Emilio and then almost went straight for me,' Jedd told Nine News.

'(They were) circling the reef, they wouldn't stop. Just around and around. It was wild.'

The trio climbed onto the nearby rocks after a bronze whaler swam directly into 17-year-old Emilio (pictured left to right: Jedd Falloon, Toby Howe and Emilio Gianfrancesco)

After the trio climbed onto the nearby rocks, they alerted Jedd's girlfriend who was standing on the beach.

Bronze whaler sharks Bronze whaler sharks are found in waters in South Africa, Australia and New Zealand. They can grow up to 3.3 metres long Bronze whalers can be known to attack humans if there is food around A person died after they were attacked by a bronze whaler in Bunker Bay, Western Australia in 2011

A Westpac helicopter arrived at the scene before a team of volunteers from the Augusta Marine Rescue came to the boy's rescue.

The trio were knee deep in water on the reef by the time the boat arrived before they were taken back to shore.

'Without them, we probably still would have been stuck out there,' Jedd said.

Despite the ordeal the spear fishers said it wouldn't stop them from going back into the water.
description: Jedd Falloon, 16, and his friends Toby Howe, 16, and Emilio Gianfrancesco, 17, were spearfishing in Hamelin Bay in Western Australia on Sunday when a bronze whaler attacked.
authors: Eliza Mcphee For Daily Mail Australia
